j:translation_en.jcr:title: Welcome text (based on the number of page views)

j:translation_en.text:
Happy to see you enjoy browsing our website

Do not hesitate to see all our content made for you

Dear Visitor

Enjoy your visit on our website

head.content:
Welcome to jExperience Demo Project

This demo project allows you to create personalizations that you can use in your websites. The project comes with a couple of ready to use examples. By following the QuickStart instructions, you can see personalizations in action within a few minutes.

QuickStart: Add personalized content to your website with 2 copy and pastes!

This personalization example displays a different welcome text in your website, depending on the number of pages viewed by the visitor.

Setup

  1. Enable data collection
    To personalize the website for individual site visitors, you need to know more about them. First need to configure data collection by copy and pasting the following script into the <head> tag in your site pages. This step is necessary for gathering data about your visitors across all of your site pages. This data will be used to determine which content to display in your personalization.

tag-perso-1.content:
1. Add the personalized content tag to your page
    Now you are ready to add the personalization to your page. Copy and paste the following personalization code in your page where the personalization needs to happen:

tag-perso-2.content:
Personalization in action

The code you copied and pasted adds a different welcome text to your website, depending on the number of pages the visitor browsed on the website.

The first two times the same visitor sees the page, the following text displays:

doc-section-1.content: The third time the visitor sees the page (refresh your browser to increase the visit count), the personalization is applied and the following text displays:

doc-section-2.content:
Note: If you need to try the test again, you can use a new private window in your browser. In the private window, you will be considered as a first time visitor. Simply refresh your browser to increase the visit count.

Congratulations, you have successfully added a personalization to your site!

Going further

  • Manage this personalization: edit the text, add new variants, update the conditions
  • Personalize images depending on a visitor's device
  • Access all the personalizations
  • Create a new personalization
  • Upload and manage images

doc-section.content:
Personalized text for multiple page views

This personalization displays a different welcome text in your website, depending on the number of pages viewed by the visitor.

Overview

Visitors who have viewed one or two pages, see the following text:

doc-section-1.content: After 3 page views (you can simply refresh a page to increase the page view count), the following text is displayed:

doc-section-3.content:
Personalization: under the hood

This section shows where you create personalizations in the jExperience back office and how you edit and update them.

Access personalizations

doc-section-2.content:
1. Click on the pencil edit icon next to the Welcome text (based on the number of page views) personalization.

You are now editing the personalization. From this page you can:

  • Edit the text variants
  • Add new variants
  • Change the conditions to display one variant or another
  • Save your changes and publish to make them available

edit-text-variants.content:
Edit the text variants

To edit text variants:

  1. In the list of variants, click on the button corresponding to the text you want to edit and then click Edit. Content Editor opens.


     
  2. Simply update the text using the rich text editor. Click on the Source button in the text editor if you need to manually update the HTML.


     
  3. Click Save in the top-right corner to save your modifications and update the preview.
  4. At this time, your modifications are still not available on your site. You need to publish your changes first. Click Publish Now to publish your modifications.
    Look at your site, you will see that the changes have been applied.
  5. Click on the back button (in the top left corner) to close Content Editor and to go back to your personalization:

add-new-variant.content:
Add new variants

To add a new variant:

  1. Click on the Add variant button.


     
  2. The Select Content Type selector opens.


     
  3. In this demo project, you can only choose one of the following options:
    • Rich text
      As described before, this provides a rich text editor where you can add styling (such as colors and titles), include images, add links, and more. You can also add source HTML code.
    • Simple text
      This is plain text with no text formatting capabilities.
    • Image
      Allows you to use an image as a variant. Learn more about images in the Personalization based on images doc.
  4. To be consistent with the others variants, create a new Rich text content. Content Editor opens.


     
  5. Write the text of your variant, click Save in the top right corner and then Publish now. Click the back button as described in the Edit the text variants section above.

change-conditions.content:
Change the conditions to display one variant or another

Access display conditions

To see the conditions in which a variant is displayed, look at the Display strategy of a personalization and the display condition defined for each variant.

In this case, the display strategy is First matching conditions. When a visitor browses a page with the personalization, content variant conditions are evaluated in the order they appear. The best practice is to order your variants with those that DO have conditions first in your list.

To see the display condition of a variant, select the variant and click on it. Then read the Condition builder section.

In this case, the Happy to see... variant is valid and displays (first of the list) when a visitor has viewed more than 2 website pages.

Update display conditions

In the Condition builder, you graphically define the logic to implement in order to validate a variant. Here you can update the current condition and change the minimum number of page views to 1 or update the Operator value to is greater than or equal to.

One or the other will have the same result, the variant display when a visitor views more than 1 website pages.

Add a new condition

The AND | OR buttons allows you to build more complex logic. To learn more about conditions, read this page.

save-changes.content:
Save your changes and publish to make them available

Once you have modified your personalization (added or removed a variant, changed the conditions display), click Save in the top right corner to save your changes.

At this time your changes are still not available on your site. You need to publish your changes first. Click Publish Now to publish.

Finally click on the back button, in the top left corner, to close the personalization editor and to go back to your personalization dashboard.

visitor-information-overview.content:
Visitor device image personalization

This personalization displays an image depending on the visitor's device. If the visitor browses the website with a mobile device, then a portrait image is displayed. Otherwise, a default landscape image is displayed.

Overview

When a visitor visits your website with a mobile device, the following image displays:

overview-doc-section-2.content: When a visitor visits your website with a device which is not a mobile device, the following image displays:

doc-section-2.content:
1. Click on the pencil edit icon next to the Images based on visitor device.

You are now editing the personalization. From this screen you can:

  • Edit the image variants
  • Add new variants
  • Change the conditions to display one variant or another
  • Save your changes and publish to make them available

edit-text-variants.content:
Edit the image variants

To edit image variants:

  1. In the list of variants, click on the button corresponding to the image you want to edit, then click Edit


     
  2. Content Editor opens.


     
  3. Update the image clicking on the thumbnail. The picker interface opens and you can browse the media repository in the demo site to find a new image or you can upload a new one.
    Note: For more about media management in jContent, see this page.


     
  4. After selecting your image, click Save in the top-right corner of Content Editor. Your changes are saved and the preview is updated.
  5. At this time, your changes are still not available on your site. You need to publish your changes first. Click Publish Now to publish your changes.
    Look at your site, you will see that the changes have been applied.
  6. Click on the back button (in the top left corner) to close Content Editor and to go back to your personalization:

add-new-variant.content:
Add new variants

To add a new variant:

  1. Click on the Add variant button.


     
  2. The Select Content Type selector opens:


     
  3. In this demo project, you can only choose one of the following options:
    • Rich text
      As described before, this provides a rich text editor where you can add styling (such as colors and titles), include images, add links, and more. You can also add source HTML code.
    • Simple text
      This is plain text with no text formatting capabilities.
    • Image
      Allows you to use an image as a variant.
  4. To be consistent with the others variants, create a new Image content. Content Editor opens.


     
  5. Click the Select an image placeholder to pick an image for your variant. Click Save in the top-right corner and Publish Now. Click the back button as explained in the Edit the image variants section above.

change-conditions.content:
Change the conditions to display one variant or another

Access points conditions

To see the conditions in which a variant is displayed, look at the Display strategy of a personalization and the display condition defined for each variant. In this case, the display strategy is Sorted by score. When a visitor reaches a page with the personalization, content variant conditions are evaluated and a score is retuned. The variant with the highest score is selected. The score is calculating based on the points conditions defined for each variant.

To see the point conditions of a variant, select the variant and click on it. Then read the Condition builder section. In this case, the Mobile Image variant assigns 1 point when the device category of the visitor viewing your site is Mobile. With 1 point the variant has the highest score, so it will be displayed.

Update display conditions

In the Condition builder, you graphically define the logic to implement in order to validate a variant. Here you can update the current condition and change the Devices selection adding Tablet.

The AND | OR buttons allow you to refine the condition to obtain the points (create a more complex logic). To learn more about conditions, read this page.

You can also change the number of points for each condition and increase the importance of one condition compared to another.

Add a new condition

Click the Add new button to create a new condition. With the new condition, you can add more points to the variant.

save-changes.content:
Save your changes and publish to make them available

Once you have modified your personalization (added or removed a variant, changed the conditions display), click Save in the top right corner to save your changes.

At this time your changes are still not available on your site. You need to publish your changes first. Click Publish Now to publish.

Finally click on the back button, in the top left corner, to close the personalization editor and to go back to your personalization dashboard.

doc-section.content:
Accessing your personalizations

To access your personalizations (including the example ones) you need to:

access-personalizations.content:
1. Open jExperience by clicking the jExperience entry in the left navigation menu.


     
  2. Once in jExperience, ensure that the right project is selected: jExperience Demo Project.

    Open jExperience
     

  3. Click on the second entry: AB tests and personalizations
  4. The demo project comes with 2 examples of personalizations:
    • Welcome text (based on the number of page views)
      this is the text personalization, used to try the personalization in 2 minutes
    • Images based on visitor devices
      this is a personalization using images

visitor-information-overview.content:
Creating a new personalization

Here you will learn the basics on how to create a new personalization. Let's define what you want to achieve: you want to create a personalization that displays an image depending on the number of pages views by the visitor. If a visitor has seen more than 2 pages of your website, you display a specific image. Otherwise, you display a default image.

Note: This tutorial assumes that you are working in the jExperience demo project.

Before taking a deep dive in the creation process, you should understand what personalization content means for jExperience.

Overview

A personalization content is a complex content item used by jExperience to store:

  • The personalization logic (based on visitor information, segment or scoring plan)
  • The content to display for each logic (variant)
  • Various information like the start date and end date of the personalization

To create a new personalization you have to follow 3 steps:

  1. Create a Personalization content
  2. Create the personalized content (text or images)
  3. Create the personalization logic

Create a Personalization content

To create your first personalization:

  1. Open jExperience by clicking the jExperience entry in the left navigation menu.



     Open jExperience
     
  2. In jExperience, ensure that the right project is selected. Select jExperience Demo Project and click on the first entry:  AB tests and personalizations.


     
  3. Click Create Personalization at the top right and add or select the following values:
    • Object Type: Content
    • Location: In a content folder
    • Content folder: Click the picker icon and select jExperience Demo Project>contents>Personalization examples
    • Display strategy: First matching conditions
    • Title: Returning visitor image perso
       

     
  4. Finally, click Save.

Now you are ready to create the first personalized content, also known as variant.

Create the personalized content

As you remember, the objective of your new personalization is to display an image depending on the visitor's number of page view. Therefore, you want to create an image as the content/variant.

  1. Click Add variant, open the Content:Multimedia list and select Image. Click Create.


     
  2. A new form appears where you can add properties for an image. Important properties are Image and Title. Let's start with Image. Click the Select an image placeholder and select an image from the picker. In this example, select the people-and-dog image.


     
  3. In Title, name the image: Returning visitor image.


     
  4. Click Save, review your content and click the Back button at the top-left of the page to return to the personalization page.


     
  5. On the personalization page, complete the previous steps again to add another variant image named New visitor image.


     

Create the personalization logic

Now you should have your New and Returning visitor Image variants available in your personalization content. Also, it is time to start on the logic. But before you do deep dive, let's start with an overview of the visitor information.

Visitor Information Overview

The information collected about your visitors can be configured as part of your jExperience setup and is a key resource for a successful personalization. To learn more, see the  jExperience>Key concepts documentation in the Academy.

Information available about your visitors falls into 3 major categories:

  1. Current Visit (Session)
    This is information specific to the current visit. Commonly available information from the visitor browser will tell you about the following: 
    • Location
      By country or by point
    • Session duration
      How long they stayed on the site
    • Device Category
      For example, desktop, mobile, tablet, anonymized, unknown
    • Session properties
      Such as, operating system, previous page, referring page
  2. Visitor properties (Profile)
    For example, first name, last name, pets and more. This information can be extensive and is unique to your jExperience system. 
    • Information collected in jExperience based on your configuration of user logins, user forms, social media account linkages, and more.
    • Information aggregated external sources using Jahia Stack Connect. 250+ sources include files, CRM and martech systems, databases, and more.
  3. Computed information
    You can define many conditions in Jahia to score and categorize users, define goals, and track campaigns.
    • Profiling
      Segments, lists, scoring plans
    • Behavioral
      Interests, pages viewed, campaign engagement, goals matched, time events
    • New/Returning
      Status of visitors who are identifiable
Next, you’ll need to decide under what conditions you want to display your variant to visitors. For this tutorial, it is recommended that you use Behavioral information to create a condition that displays a specific variant to visitors seeing at least 3 pages of the website and a default variant to all other users.

doc-section.content:
Configuring your personalization and display strategy

Prerequisites

Review the Display Strategy. Be sure you choose First content matching conditions so that you can try out building a condition based on Behavioral information.

Next, you’ll need to specify the conditions for each variant. In other words, you’ll choose which variants display to different visitors to your website.

Define conditions

Based on your Display Strategy, when a visitor browses a page with personalization, content variant conditions are evaluated in the order they appear. Therefore, it is best practice to order your variants with those that DO have conditions first in your list.

For this tutorial, you have a specific variant you want to display to users seeing at least 3 pages of the website, and another for all other users. Logically, you want to say something like:

IF "number of page views if greater than" then display X, ELSE display Y

It makes sense to bring the returning condition to the top of your list.

  1. Select the variant that you want to set a condition for and move it to the top of the list.
    Hint: Select and hold the move icon =  to move variants up and down in the list.


     

    Note: The fallback variant checkbox is mandatory. Select this for the variant that you want to display when no conditions are met.

     
  2. Click the radio button on the first content variant. Then, the Condition Builder appears.


     
  3.  Now you are ready to create the condition for mobile visitors. Select the Custom option and click Behavioral.


     
  4. From the Behavioral options, select Number of pages viewed on the site.


     
  5. Now you can specify the details of the condition. In this tutorial, you will create a condition where the number of pages viewed on the site is greater than 2. For Number of page views, select is greater than from the dropdown and enter 2.


     

    Note: The AND | OR buttons allow you to build more complex logic. To learn more about conditions, see Conditions Builder.

     
  6. In the Options section and under Duration, you can specify when you want your personalization to Start and End, no selection is required.
  7. To use your new personalization content, copy the code snippet from the External site snippet section.


     
  8. Click Save and Publish Now and exit personalization by clicking the back arrow.
     

Congratulations, you have defined your first personalization condition!

accessing-media.content:
Uploading and managing images

Files are stored under the parent files folder, which is a different location from the content and personalizations that reference them. 

  • The media files used in the personalization variants are stored and managed in the jContent interface under the parent files folder. You can access and organize your files from the Media section in jContent.
  • Each item in jContent has a context menu with supported actions such as preview, open, edit, lock, and publish.
  • Once contributed or modified, files need to be published in order to be available online.

Note: The jContent interface is the same whether you use it for personalization only or if you use it to contribute content in a site. This documentation page is actually built using jContent's CMS capabilities.

Accessing the media folders Open the media folder

You open jContent from the left navigation menu:

  1. Click jContent  in the left navigation pane. jContent opens. You can ignore the Pages section as it contains this documentation content.
  2. Open Media from the navigation pane to browse your files and images.

managing-files-folders.content:
Creating folders

You can create folders from the Media section in jContent.

To create new content or folders:

  1. Click the + New folder button. The following characters are not allowed in the content folder name: \/:*?"<>|.
    Note: You can also click the More options button  beside an existing folder to open the context menu and create a sub-folder from there.
  2. Enter a folder name and click OK.

Uploading files

You can upload files from the Media section. For example, you can upload images, videos, and documents.

To upload a file:

  1. Navigate to the folder that you want to upload a file to.
  2. Drag-and-drop the file from your computer to the folder content area. When you drop the file, the upload starts automatically. Alternatively you can click the Upload file(s) button, navigate to the file on your computer, and then upload the file in your browser.
  3. If you upload a file in a folder that already contains a file with the same name, then a file conflict occurs. To resolve the conflict, you can rename the file that you want to upload, overwrite the file on jContent, or cancel the upload.
    • To rename the file that you want to upload, click Rename and enter a new file name in the dialog.
    • To replace the version of the file on jContent, click Replace.
    • To cancel the file upload, click Don’t upload.

Modifying images

You can rotate, resize, and crop images in the Media section.

To edit an image:

  1. Navigate to the folder that contains the image you want to edit.
  2. Right-click the image and select Open in image editor. The image editor opens.
  3. Select the operation you want to perform:
    • Rotate
      Click the Rotate left or Rotate right icon the rotate the image.
    • Resize
      Type the desired width or height. By default, the width and height ratio is locked. To edit the width or height independently, click the ratio icon to unlock the width and height relationship.
    • Crop
      Use the crop tool in the preview to select the area of the image you want to crop. You can also adjust its size, by manually editing the width and height. The ratio can also be locked and unlocked.
Note: You cannot combine different operations before saving. Once you have started editing an image, you need to either Undo changes or Save your changes before performing another operation. When using the Save as option, a copy of the image is created, and this copy is automatically opened in the image editor.

Deleting files

You can delete files that you no longer require. You can delete individual files and delete entire folders. Before you delete a file, you must first mark it for deletion. If the file has never been published, you can delete it permanently from the system. Otherwise, you must publish the deletion to delete the file.

Important: When you delete a file, it is permanently deleted and cannot be recovered.

To mark files for deletion:

  1. Navigate to the folder that contains the files that you want to delete.
  2. Open the context menu of the file or folder and select Delete. 
    A confirmation window displays if the content is in use in a site or referenced by other content.
  3. Click Yes in the Delete Selection dialog.
    A lock icon displays beside the content item in the list.

Deleting an unpublished file or folder

Before deleting content, you must first mark the content for deletion.

To delete an unpublished content item or folder:

  1. Ensure that you have marked the content item for deletion.
  2. Open the context menu of the content item or folder and select Delete (permanently).
    This menu entry is also available in the More options button in the preview pane.
  3. Click Yes in the Delete Selection dialog.
Note: Files marked for deletion which have never been published will also be permanently deleted if it is part of a publication process. For example, files marked for deletion are deleted if their parent folder is published.

Deleting published files

Files that you mark for deletion are permanently deleted when you publish them. Therefore, you must start the publication of a file marked for deletion to permanently delete its live version.

To delete published files:

  1. Ensure that you have marked the files for deletion.
  2. Open the context menu of the item or folder and select Publish deletion.
    The Publication dashboard page displays.
    Note: You can also access Publish deletion when you preview an item.
  3. To verify the contents of the publication and to avoid publishing undesired modifications, click Publication infos and review your changes.
  4. Depending on your role, you can either:
    • Publish the content yourself by clicking Publish.
    • Request publication by clicking Request publication to start a publication workflow. For information on completing the publication workflow, consult our online documentation.
Important: When you or another user publishes the files, they are permanently deleted from the system.

publication-doc.content:
Publishing

Publishing content and files

You can publish content yourself if you have the appropriate permissions. You can also request publication to start a publication workflow.

To publish content:

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders or Media in the navigation pane.
  2. Navigate to the folder that contains the content or files that you want to publish.
  3. Open the context menu by either:
    • Hovering over the content or file and clicking the More options button.
    • Previewing the content or file by clicking Publish in the preview pane.
  4. In the context menu, click on Publish - current language or Publish in all languages.
  5. In the Publication dashboard page, verify the content you are about to publish.
  6. Depending on your role, you can either:
    • Publish the content yourself by clicking Publish.
    • Request publication by clicking Request publication to start a publication workflow. For information on completing the publication workflow, consult our online documentation.
Note: You can also select several content items (or files when using the List view) and click the Publish button in the action bar to publish several content items or files at once.

Publishing a folder

You can publish a folder yourself if you have the appropriate permissions. You can also request publication to start a publication workflow.

To publish a folder:

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders or Media in the navigation pane.
  2. Navigate to the folder you want to publish.
  3. In the header, click the Publish button to publish the content of your folder in the current language. Alternatively, click on the drop down button next to the Publish button, and select Publish all under current folder - current language or  Publish all under current folder in all languages
    Note: You can also navigate to the folder that contains the folder that you want to publish. And then select one of these publication options in the context menu of the folder.
  4. In the Publication dashboard page, verify the content you are about to publish
  5. Depending on your role, you can either:
    • Publish the folder yourself by clicking on Publish.
    • Request publication by clicking on Request publication to start a publication workflow. For more information on completing the publication workflow, consult our online documentation.

Unpublishing

This section shows how to  upublish content and files, and pages and folders.

Unpublishing content and files

You can unpublish content yourself if you have the appropriate permissions. You can also request publication to start a publication workflow.

To unpublish content or files:

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders or Media in the navigation pane.
  2. Navigate to the folder that contains the content or files that you want to unpublish.
  3. Open the context menu by either:
    • Hovering over the content or file and clicking the More options button.
    • Previewing the content or file by clicking Publish in the preview pane.
  4. In the context menu, click on Unpublish - current language or Unpublish in all languages.
  5. In the Publication dashboard page, verify the content you are about to unpublish.
  6. Depending on your role, you can either:
    • Publish the content yourself by clicking Unpublish.
    • Request publication by clicking Request unpublication to start a publication workflow. For information on completing the publication workflow, consult our online documentation.
Note: You can also select several content items (or files when using the List view) and click the drop down next to the publish button in the action bar to unpublish several content items or files at once.

Unpublishing folders

To unpublish folders:

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders or Media in the navigation pane.
  2. Navigate to the folder you want to  unpublish.
  3. In the header, click the drop down button next to the Publish button, and select Unpublish current page/folder - current language or  Unpublish current page/folder in all languages
  4. Depending on your role, you can either:
    • Unpublish the content yourself by clicking Unpublish.
    • Request unpublication by clicking Request unpublication to start a workflow. For more information on completing the unpublication workflow, consult our online documentation.

doc-opening-jcontent.content:
Managing content

This topic is for users who are already confident with creating personalizations and with updating variants. It shows how to manage variants outside of the personalization page.

When creating a new personalization, you need to specify in which content folder the personalization will be located. Using jContent to access the content, the variants of your personalizations, you will be able to leverage jContent capabilities to ease the management of your content.

Once contributed or modified, content must be published to be available online. You work on the staging version of your content until it's ready to be published.

Note: The jContent interface is the same whether you use it for personalization only or if you use it to contribute content in a site. This documentation page is actually built using of jContent's CMS capabilities.

Opening jContent Open the content folder

You open jContent from the left navigation menu:

  1. Click jContent  in the left navigation pane. jContent opens. You can ignore the Pages section as it contains this documentation content.
  2. Open Content Folders from the navigation pane to browse the folders containing your personalizations and their variants.

doc-create-content.content:
Working with content folders

This section shows you how to create a content folder, provide an alternative folder name, restrict the types of content that are allowed in a folder, and add content to a folder.

Creating content folders

You can create new content and folders from the Content Folders page in jContent.

To create new content or folders:

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders in the left navigation pane.
  2. To create a new folder:
    1. Click the + New content folder button. The following characters are not allowed in the content folder name: \/:*?"<>|.
      Note: You can also click the More options button  beside an existing folder to open the context menu and create a sub-folder from there.
    2. Enter a folder name and click OK.

Restricting content types for a folder

You can restrict the types of content that users can create for a personalization, by restricting the types of content users can create in the personalization parent folder. This enables you have specialized folders to manage where content is created and stored. For example, you may only want users to be able to create news items in a news folder.

Only users with the View content type restriction tab permission can set restrictions. This permission is granted by default to site administrators only.
Note: Folder restrictions only apply to new content that users create in the folder.

To restrict content types in a folder:

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders in the navigation pane.
  2. Open the context menu for the folder and select Edit.
  3. On the edit content page, select Advanced options>Content type restrictions.
  4. Enable Content type restrictions.
  5. Move the content types that you want to allow in the folder from the left column to the right column.
  6. Click Save.

Creating new variants from jContent

This section shows how to add a new variant to an existing personalization.

For information on defining the types of content that can be created for a personalization, see Restricting content types for a folder.

Note: The option to create new variants is also available from the context menu of the personalization.

To create new variant:

  1. Navigate to the folder containing your personalization.
  2. Double click on the personalization, so you can see the list of variants.
  3. From there, you can:
    • Create a new variant from scratch:
      1. Click the + New content button and select a content type.
        Note: If less than 3 different content types are specified for the current folder, then buttons to directly select these content types replace the + New content button.
      2. Provide information about the content. For more information on what you can add, see Using Content Editor.
      3. Click Save.
    • Duplicate an existing variant
      1. Right click on the variant, then select Copy.
        Note: You can also copy a content from a different personalization or folder.
      2. Click the Paste button in the toolbar (right above the content list).
      3. You can open the created variant for editing by:
        • Hovering your cursor over a content item in the list and clicking on the edit button.
        • Right-clicking on a content item and then selecting Edit.
    • Import previously exported content (see below).

Editing the personalization to specify the conditions

As you have just added a variant directly from jContent, you need to edit the personalization. This can be done from jExperience and the personalization list. You can also right-click on the personalization in jContent, then click Edit personalization.

Opening content for editing

You can open content for editing in Content Editor by:

  • Hovering your cursor over a content item in the list and clicking on the edit button.
  • Right-clicking on a content item and then selecting Edit.

Previewing content

Previewing content makes it easier for you to identify the different content items inside a page, a folder or in search results. Preview also enables you to quickly see a visual representation of content in both its staging and live versions.

To preview content:

  1. In jContent, navigate to the page or folder that contains content that you want to preview.
  2. Hover your cursor over an item in the list and click on the preview button .
    The Preview pane displays the staging version of the content item.
  3. Click Live to preview to the published version of the content.
Note: You can use the keyboard arrow keys to navigate between the content items you are previewing.

Exporting content

You can export content from the Page and Content Folders sections. For example, you can export lists, rich text, and news entries.

To export content: 

  1. Navigate to the page or content folder where you want to export content from.
  2. Right-click and select Export from the context menu. 
  3. In the Export options dialog, select either Staging content only or Staging and live content.
  4. If you chose Staging content only, you can select to Export to an XML file to export as an XML file rather than a ZIP file.
  5. Click Export.

The content exports to your default download location.

Importing content

You can import content from the Content Folders section. For example, you can import lists, rich text, and news entries.

To import content: 

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders in the navigation pane.
  2. Navigate to the content folder where you want to import content to.
  3. Right-click on Import content from the context menu or the Create menu.
  4. Navigate to the XML or ZIP file on your machine and then import the file in your browser. Alternatively, you can drag-and-drop the XML or ZIP file from your machine to the content folder area. When you drop the file, the import starts automatically.

If you import a file in another format, an error message displays. You can either close the message or click Don't import.

Note: You can import multiple files at once, either by selecting them in your browser or dragging-and-dropping them to the content folder area.

doc-deletion.content:
Deleting content

You can delete content that you no longer require. You can delete individual content items and delete entire folders. Before you delete content, you must first mark it for deletion. If the content has never been published, you can delete the content permanently from the system. Otherwise, you must publish the deletion to delete the content.

Important: When you delete content, it is permanently deleted and cannot be recovered. If you simply want content to no be longer visible online, then consider unpublishing the content instead of deleting it.
Unpublished content is still editable in its staging version. Remember to unpublish the content in the desired language if your content exists in several languages. You can also unpublish a content item so that it is no longer visible online for a selected language.

Important: Deleting content in one language also deletes the content in any other languages in which it exists.

Marking content for deletion

Before deleting content, you must first mark it for deletion.

To mark content for deletion:

  1. In jContent, click Content Folders in the left pane.
  2. Navigate to the folder that contains content that you want to delete.
  3. Open the context menu of the content or folder and select Delete. 
    A confirmation window displays if the content is in use in a site or referenced by other content.
  4. Click Yes in the Delete Selection dialog.
    A lock icon displays beside the content item in the list.

Deleting an unpublished content item or folder

Before deleting content, you must first mark the content for deletion.

To delete an unpublished content item or folder:

  1. Ensure that you have marked the content item for deletion.
  2. Open the context menu of the content item or folder and select Delete (permanently).
    This menu entry is also available in the More options button in the preview pane.
  3. Click Yes in the Delete Selection dialog.
Note: Content marked for deletion which has never been published will also be permanently deleted if it is part of a publication process. For example, content marked for deletion is deleted if its parent folder is published.

Deleting published content

Content that you mark for deletion is permanently deleted when you publish it. Therefore, you must start the publication of a content item marked for deletion to permanently delete its live version.

Note: Content is considered to be published if it has been published and unpublished in the past.

To delete published content:

  1. Ensure that you have marked the content item for deletion.
  2. Open the context menu of the item or folder and select Publish deletion.
    The Publication dashboard page displays.
    Note: You can also access Publish deletion when you preview an item.
  3. To verify the contents of the publication and to avoid publishing undesired modifications, click Publication infos and review your changes.
  4. Depending on your role, you can either:
    • Publish the content yourself by clicking Publish.
    • Request publication by clicking Request publication to start a publication workflow. For information on completing the publication workflow, consult our online documentation.
Important: When you or another user publishes the content, it is permanently deleted from the system.
